title: We watched PSG win Champions League final with a professional head coach â€“ here what we learned
body_text:
â€œTheyâ€™ve scored five goals, but the defensive work was the key thing that won the game,â€ says Ian Cathro, verging on cliche.
Paris Saint-Germain had just beaten Inter 5-0 in Munich, the biggest winning margin in a Champions League final but, while everyone marvelled at Desire Doueâ€™s brilliance, PSGâ€™s positional rotations and Vitinhaâ€™s midfield orchestrating, Cathroâ€™s focus was elsewhere.
UEFA Pro Licence coaches watch the game differently. Itâ€™s their job.
Advertisement
Cathro â€” once an assistant to Nuno Espirito Santo at Rio Ave, Valencia, Wolverhampton Wanderers (where he coached PSGâ€™s Vitinha), Tottenham Hotspur and Al-Ittihad â€” this season led top-tier Portuguese side Estoril to their best finish in nine years.
They forced the most offsides of any Primeira Liga team, ranked fourth for ball recoveries and sixth for final-third tackles. No wonder he admires PSGâ€™s out-of-possession approach.
â€œPSGâ€™s pressure has taken Inter out of their normal routines with the ball, and thatâ€™s the thing that helps you grow into a final. When the magnitude of the game is higher, routines are more important. Theyâ€™ve taken that away from them completely,â€ he says.
â€œInter have a lot of mobility if you donâ€™t press the first ball circulation, but they canâ€™t get into funky positions if you start pressing them straight away â€” because they have to hold their spaces to take on that pressure.â€
He spots a detail with Achraf Hakimiâ€™s pressing on 23 minutes, just after PSGâ€™s second goal. â€œAs he was starting to run, he went three metres inside and stopped them slamming forward to a striker, forcing the ball to the wing-back (white arrow). Thatâ€™s when you know theyâ€™ve nailed the work, to stop those inside line passes (yellow arrow), theyâ€™ve never been unbalanced.â€
â€œPSG are trying to press the ball outside and around. The break point would be if you were able to get the ball to the side and go diagonally in.â€
Inter could not in this instance. Joao Neves is too tight to Henrikh Mkhitaryan while Hakimiâ€™s pressure and readjustment blocks any inside pass, forcing Federico Dimarco long.
Inter No 9 Lautaro Martinez has dropped deeper to try and support, with PSG centre-back Marquinhos staying touch-tight.
Dimarco targets his strike partner, Marcus Thuram.
Neves recovers and Willian Pacho closes Thuram to make a two-v-one for PSG. Neves tackles the France international.
â€œItâ€™s a lot of work,â€ Cathro says on coaching a high press. â€œItâ€™s the most difficult bit to get to perfection. Youâ€™re playing against highly proficient technical players with their own ideas.â€
Advertisement
When an almost identical pressing pattern happens eight minutes later, Cathroâ€™s praise switches to Vitinha. Dimarco is forced long once more, this time on his right foot, and Vitinha stays tight to Martinez before ducking as he reads that the striker wonâ€™t be able to make the flick-on. The ball runs through to Marquinhos.
â€œWhat he has done there is excellent. Not competing for that ball, not letting that ball land, and now they can turn it into possession. PSGâ€™s pressing â€” the little details â€” has been really good.â€
In the second half, he lauds Ousmane Dembele for forcing Inter goalkeeper Yann Sommer to kick long. â€œSo if he has to go and lift it, heâ€™s lifting it either across his body and he has to do it early â€” because youâ€™ll get close to his right foot â€” or you force him on his left.â€
Against PSGâ€™s press, Sommer hit nearly 43 per cent of passes long (his season average is 28 per cent in Serie A and the Champions League). Luis Enriqueâ€™s side made the first contact on half of his long passes.
One sequence, with PSG 4-0 up on 77 minutes, makes Cathro say â€œwowâ€ (none of the goals did). As Inter recycle into the middle from the right wing against a PSG low block, Vitinha presses substitute Kristjan Asllani when he receives Darmianâ€™s sideways pass.
Cathro pointed out the mid-block pressing trigger in the first half: â€œThe ball going from one side to the other and then backwards. The PSG back-line gets as high as they can, which, compared to gradually dropping, changes so much.â€
Within three seconds, five PSG players have committed to press and centre-back Francesco Acerbi is facing his own goal â€” Dembele is on top of him.
Inter end up playing all the way back to Sommer, PSG lock on and Dembele presses him into kicking long.
Luis Enriqueâ€™s side have stepped up so quickly that they catch Martinez offside. Five PSG players â€” including incoming substitute Lucas Hernandez â€” have already got their hands up appealing.
I ask Cathro if he would clap or praise that same press from his Estoril side. â€œYeah, Iâ€™m rewarding that. I know itâ€™s not a goal, but that really needs to be rewarded because thatâ€™s the intensity, concentration, and maintaining the focus. You know that that has such an impact on the opponent as well. It takes a lot away from them.â€
Advertisement
â€œI donâ€™t remember a situation where Inter have actually been able to pass feet-to-feet centrally while PSG have been pressing. PSG have really worked hard at taking away those lines inside, and theyâ€™ve forced predictable circulations of the ball, meaning theyâ€™ve been able to get closer and closer, force mistakes and regains. Their work against the ball has been exceptional.â€
His first-half critique of Inter is that they were â€œclose to passiveâ€. He finds using the word as an absolute â€œreally offensive. Itâ€™s not nice, but it was in that direction.â€
PSG completed over 100 passes inside the first 15 minutes â€” three sequences of 10+ passes â€” and Inter only recorded two tackles and two interceptions, content to slide and shuffle in their 5-3-2 block.
Cathroâ€™s analysis was that Inter were â€œactively trying to trap the ball on one side. Theyâ€™re sitting, theyâ€™re allowing a fair bit. When somebody allows you to do something, thatâ€™s because theyâ€™re planning to do something to you.
â€œWeâ€™ve not seen one Inter counter-attacking situation from established PSG attacks. They regained it on the midfield line and slammed it forward to the two strikers once.
â€œThey switched it to the right side and you thought, â€˜OK, maybe this is the counter that theyâ€™re looking forâ€™. Theyâ€™ve not had a possession thatâ€™s forced PSG to drop back into shape once.
â€œIf they want to try and trap us on the same side, then Iâ€™d (PSG) be looking to repeat (attack again) that side with a different movement or a different mobility â€” try and profit from their plans.â€
â€œSame sideâ€ is a phrase Cathro repeats a lot when talking about attacks, explaining how PSG reworked the situation down the left to create the cutback from Doue to Hakimi for the opening goal.
Acerbi steps forward when Fabian Ruiz passes backwards to Vitinha. This makes space for a through ball to Doue, and the domino effect is that Dimarco (having played Doue onside) scrambles across to cover. He was marking Hakimi and ends up neither stopping the full-back nor blocking the cutback, and the Moroccan taps in.
Quarter-final goal âœ…
Semi-final goal âœ…
Final goal âœ…Achraf Hakimi gives PSG an early lead in the Champions League final, but refuses to celebrate against his former side Inter âš½
ğŸ“º @tntsports & @discoveryplusUK pic.twitter.com/6nNcCd1dv0
â€” Football on TNT Sports (@footballontnt) May 31, 2025
Cathro likes the word â€œmobilityâ€ to describe full-backs and wingers interchanging, and says it is important, â€œespecially against a back three. When the outside centre-backs start to feel that they lose their references (for marking) â€” because thereâ€™s a certain distance where they feel like, â€˜Iâ€™m controlling this oneâ€™ and then thereâ€™s the point where theyâ€™re not controlling anyone directly â€” that creates that little gapâ€.
Advertisement
What would he have done if he were Simone Inzaghi? He caveats that â€œthereâ€™s definitely a non-tactical element in this,â€ and that a â€œlimited number of impactful things can happenâ€. The 38-year-old speaks from experience, having been Nunoâ€™s assistant at Rio Ave in May 2014 when they lost two domestic cup finals to Benfica and were behind at half-time in both.
Tactically, his focus would be to â€œget another player in the middle and try and force the middle of the pitch. See if that just forces PSG to have more doubts when theyâ€™re pressing. Because if they have to run too far away from the middle or all midfielders need to be engaged in pressure, they may not feel comfortable, knowing that thereâ€™s two strikers behindâ€.
He points out it takes 27 minutes for a pass to stick from the back line into a striker â€” from Sommer looping a drop-kick into Thuram â€” before Inter work a wide triangle with two midfielders combining to put Denzel Dumfries into a crossing position. PSG cleared it but Thuram and Martinez were two-v-two in the box.
Twelve of Interâ€™s 19 crosses came from the right, and Cathro spots a pattern on 28 minutes that kept creating crossing positions down the right.
â€œThatâ€™s two maybe, three times, that diagonal in-to-out run down the right has been made. PSG havenâ€™t been close enough to it and the cross has been possible. A lot of teams, when theyâ€™re closer to their box in that situation, donâ€™t send the centre back â€” they send the midfielder.
â€œIf Inter get into that position and are high enough up, that diagonal run for the ball down the line might leave a player free because the centre-back isnâ€™t going to want to come.â€
His less tactical solution owes to â€œthe Scottish part of my psyche. The Inter team â€” older, more experienced, more years, they can see the goal (trophy) â€” Iâ€™m surprised that thereâ€™s not been a bigger kind of physical moment to try and reset the order of the game a little bitâ€.
Advertisement
Just getting to a higher position and staying there, having five minutes of more intensity, get against them, hit them. Sometimes you lose a ball higher up, somebody slips away and you go, â€˜Youâ€™re going on the ground, my friendâ€™. Create maybe a little bit of chaos.
â€œGet the referee involved in the game, from the point of view that youâ€™ve got the experience to handle that and provoke them a little bit. Remind them that football has got other things to it â€” not everything is how you build up and how you press.â€
Cathro starts thinking about his half-time team talks from no earlier than 41 minutes in. In Luis Enriqueâ€™s position, he says he would be demanding more â€œsame-side work, rather than trying to get around to the opposite sideâ€.
Inzaghi, Cathro thinks, should call on desperate measures in desperate times. â€œRip the piece of paper up and start again. Iâ€™d be adapting completely and Iâ€™d be going on top of them.
â€œHe knows a point must come where this game has to be provoked in a completely different way.
â€œInzaghi knows, if his team gets a little bit more unstable, you shoot (for a comeback) too soon and it rebounds, the gameâ€™s overâ€.
With the score unchanged at 60 minutes, PSG start to drop deeper and Cathro says his focus would be on pressing, â€œbecause right now youâ€™re fighting the beginning of a comeback. Everythingâ€™s got to come out (physically) in the next three to five minutesâ€.
There are two minor, ultimately inconsequential moments, first from Joao Neves and then Nuno Mendes, which he quickly verbalises a dislike for.
â€œThat would piss me off â€” Neves tried to half-volley a pass in behind. Because those little things could be like a virus. Iâ€™d be losing my voice making sure he looked at me for eye contact for a split second.â€
My head is actually in my notebook on 76 minutes because PSG goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma has just caught an inswinging Inter corner and is laying on the ball.
Advertisement
â€œNuno Mendes has just slapped an awful pass across the pitch, which would send me insane,â€ Cathro says. I look up and rewind. Under no real pressure, he underhit a Hollywood pass to substitute Bradley Barcola, and Inter are attacking again.
But PSG are 4-0 up. Cathro says â€œthe game is overâ€. Why does it matter?
â€œYouâ€™re trying to stay on top of this. You donâ€™t want s*** decisions to slip in, you donâ€™t want arrogance, you donâ€™t want the lack of concentration, you donâ€™t s****y bouncing passes. You want to be on it.
â€œI want 10 minutes of clean, controlled, stand-tall, chest-out, â€˜We are the champions, we will play that wayâ€™. No s***, donâ€™t want any s***e. It finishes 4-0.â€
Only once does he take any real pleasure from an attacking action: Vitinha on 62 minutes when he sprints over to take a free kick short in PSGâ€™s own half. He plays one-twos with Hakimi and Marquinhos, the latter finding him with his back to goal against the press, and the No 6 turns before he splits Inter with a pass to Dembeleâ€™s feet.
Then he runs on to complete another one-two from Dembeleâ€™s backheel, and threads through Doue with PSG on a three-v-two overload.
The pass is so well weighted that the teenager, sprinting, can finish one-touch past Sommer at the near post.
It's Desire Doue's world and we're just living in it ğŸŒŸ
The 19-year-old makes it two goals and an assist in the Champions League final ğŸ”¥
ğŸ“º @tntsports & @discoveryplusUK pic.twitter.com/t5J0AQaMWf
â€” Football on TNT Sports (@footballontnt) May 31, 2025
Presumably owing to the coaching Cathro gave Vitinha when he was on loan at Wolves in 2020-21?
â€œNo, itâ€™s not! Heâ€™d done that himself, that goal,â€ he responds, enthusing about â€œthe intensity in all of his positioning and all of his actions and all his asks for the ball, deep in his own half, to then decide, â€˜Iâ€™ll actually run forwardâ€™. It changed everything. I thought, â€˜Why are you running forward?â€™
â€œTechnically, he had all of those things when he was at Wolves. The intensity he didnâ€™t have, or the taking responsibility aspect. It was just going through time. We didnâ€™t really do much for him.
Advertisement
â€œHe certainly would have wanted a lot more out of his time at Wolves â€” youâ€™re a really talented kid that comes through an academy, always winning, always playing, then you arrive at a club and Joao Moutinho and Ruben Neves are the two midfielders, so youâ€™re not playing. Theyâ€™re playing, and itâ€™s as simple as that. Because theyâ€™re better.
â€œBut it was an important year for him. He probably needed the difficulty and the sort of realisation of how difficult it is, and thatâ€™s probably what happened. He grew up a lot, it got him ready for when he went back to Porto and he really excelled.â€
Cathro summarises it as â€œa game where a team playing fearless and being themselves outdoes the more wise, strategic approach â€” I think thatâ€™s healthy for football.
â€œPSG finally winning with this team is also healthy. A young, hungry, obviously highly talented, high-potential team, that functions a lot more as a team.â€
When the camera cuts to a crestfallen Inzaghi, I ask if coaches naturally empathise with others in those difficult moments. â€œEverybody watching this game knows that this is a good Inter team and a fully-grown man who knows exactly what heâ€™s doing â€” he doesnâ€™t need anybodyâ€™s pity.â€
It is not unempathetic but the cut-throat realism that elite coaches need. â€œItâ€™s been a game of football and itâ€™s fallen to a certain side because of maybe three or four things. Youâ€™re on the wrong side of it today, mate. Life goes on.â€
What does he reckon Inzaghiâ€™s thinking right before the final whistle?
â€œIâ€™m wanting the press conference to finish and I want to go on holiday.â€
